question: What effect does recycling aluminum have on the amount of waste sent to landfills in communities?

content.source_1: Using recycled aluminum instead of primary aluminum uses up to 95% less energy, substantially lowering production costs; in competitive markets, lower production costs tend to lead to lower prices for aluminum-containing goods.
content.source_2: Aluminum containers can be melted and remanufactured into new products without significant loss of quality.
content.source_3: Aluminum is one of the most widely and repeatedly recycled consumer packaging materials, with established collection and remelting infrastructure.
content.source_4: Municipal curbside recycling programs bear significant costs for collection, sorting, and contamination control; when commodity prices are weak, revenue from selling recovered materials, including aluminum, often fails to cover those costs, creating budget gaps.
content.source_5: Municipal budget gaps from solid-waste and recycling operations are commonly closed via higher service fees or taxes assessed on residents and local businesses.
content.source_6: Prices for recyclable commodities, including aluminum scrap, are volatile and can decline for extended periods due to global market shifts, making municipal recycling revenues uncertain.

answer: People will add less to landfills.
